the fact this game still looks good

I‚Äôd love if we collectively decided to blow the dust off a special little game that‚Äôs been sitting in our libraries for a long, long, long damn time.

Day of Defeat Source‚Äôs entry bar might seem daunting at first, as you need to have a decent knowledge of the ins and outs just to have a merely ‚Äúdecent‚Äù time in servers where you walk among gods who have over 3k hours of experience, but it has a lot of unique quirks that make it an experience that you‚Äôll be hard-pressed to find in a modern shooter.

Movement feels snappy and precise but not *too* exploitable and you won‚Äôt find the bhoppin‚Äô crowd. You also have a stamina meter that keeps you from running too much and forces you to move smartly so that you don‚Äôt have to stop constantly to replenish the bar.

The action is satisfying but not always immediate, there‚Äôs a lot of ‚Äúdown‚Äù time where maybe you‚Äôre just waiting for a target while sitting on your ass in front of a window with your light machinegun or sniper rifle. Then some dude behind you bitch-slaps you with a shovel and makes you think very bad things regarding their mother. 
But that‚Äôs a fundemental part of the experience.

The weapons feel great: excellent sound design, animations and impact but the recoil? Yeesh, get used to that. It‚Äôs worse than anything in Counter-Strike (and for a good reason too, I‚Äôd imagine that keeping a steady aim with a .30 cal in real life would be about as pleasant and easy as working at Activision)

The arcade-ish simplicity of an old-style shooter but the competitive, slow-paced, ‚Äúcheck every corner because some dingus with a bazooka is sitting near the door frame ready to pulverize your kneecaps‚Äù type of mentality that modern shooters thrive on due to the increasing interest on ESports.

Of course, being on the Source engine, you don‚Äôt need to have your super powerful rig that you use to play your incredibly demanding titles such as Terraria and League of Legends. You can max this shit‚Äôs graphics on your mom‚Äôs 2010 busted laptop. Don‚Äôt believe it? Steal it and try it out yourself.

And, hey, the game looks great even now: what it lacks in its slightly off-looking textures it more than makes up for with its excellent modeling and fluid animations that make Back 4 Blood look like something a mentally underdeveloped monkey would code in an evening.

I especially like its attention to detail with cool little things such as helmets flying off the characters‚Äô heads when shot and soldiers putting aside their weapons while running. It‚Äôs charming.

DoD: Source is an excellent mix of new and old that may not click at first, but could easily become a neat li‚Äôl surprise when you run out of things to try out in your never-ending backlog-traveling torture.

Who knows? A couple of hundred new players sure would not hurt. It's a great game, come and have fun.

Personally i quite like this game, it has a good community and i haven't encountered many toxic players so far. I can see why people didn't like the DOD games back in the day since every other video game on the market was a generic WW2 shooter with mediocre graphics but looking back at this in 2022 i can quite enjoy game without looking at it as a generic WW2 shooter from 2010. 7.5/10

Funny shovel man killed me 108 times

Comparing DOD:Source with DOD (classic) I realized that almost nothing has changed. All the same kind and positive people, the same atmosphere as before. There is even a server with Realism that surprised and delighted me a lot.

The only thing that still spoils the mood and the desire to play is a terrible return. If you like to shoot from a machine gun, I'm afraid to upset that this is a difficult task here.

If at least someone released a guide to recoil then it would be very fixable, otherwise you just have to move the mouse on the random to try to hit.

Online is very different from DOD, there are more people and there is a variety of game modes.

In the right servers (which there's a good handful) this game is pure gold. Amazing level design and gameplay with some extremely satisfying weapons. Fun tight knit community and they're also mostly friendly. A lot of FF servers which can be good or bad, but there's servers with that disabled too. Some of the controls can feel clunky at first but will grow on you and feel good over time. I hope Valve updates this game because it's still great today and I prefer to play this over TF2 and CS 1.6 or any other WW2 shooter. Keep DoD:S alive! Two dollars on sale, you can't beat it!
